dataset.title: Effects of waterhole closures, fire, and rainfall on vegetation structure and small mammal communities

abstract.para: The issue of waterholes is a critical one for Kruger Park management. Though initially constructed to boost numbers of antelope and other animal species, many studies have demonstrated the negative effects of artificial waterholes, which create a zone of decreased biodiversity known as a piosphere (Gaylard et al.). One year prior to our study, students from the Organization of Tropical Studies did a rodent trapping study to examine the effects of artificial waterholes on rodent diversity by comparing rodent communities at an open waterhole and one that had been inactive for two years. We used similar live-trapping methods to examine the effects of one more year of inactivity at the closed waterhole, as well as the effects of a burn that had occurred at the closed waterhole within the past year. Similar to the previous study, we found significantly greater rodent and grass diversity at the closed waterhole. The overall rodent abundance was lower for our study than the previous study, likely due to the decreased grass cover at both sites. We also found dramatically increased numbers of the bushveld gerbil, Tatera leucogaster, at the burned site, supporting the notion that burning has an effect on rodent species composition.

section.title: Live trapping method
section.para: Live trapping study. In order to compare our trapping data to those from the previous year, we used the same open and closed waterholes as our study sites (open: 22°42’18" S, 31°09’43" E; closed: 22°49’40" S, 31°14’21" E, see Figure 1). Live trapping was conducted over 4 days (April 9-12, 2005). Two trapping grids were laid out on either side of the water troughs. We attempted to replicate the orientation and exact location of the grids in last year’s study, which had been placed approximately 20m from the waterholes to avoid severe overgrazing and trampling. Each grid included 30 traps (5 × 6) spaced 10 m apart. Within each line of traps we used two long Sherman traps (8 × 9.5 × 30 cm) and four short (8 × 9 × 23 cm). The distribution of the long traps within each row was randomized. To prevent any animals from experiencing hypothermia due to the damp conditions at the beginning of the study, pieces of synthetic stuffing were placed in each trap to absorb water and provide additional insulation. Traps were baited with seed each evening and were checked each morning. The traps were left open throughout the day and night. We identified each trapped individual with a unique marking using black hair dye. We used a single numbering system for both grids at each site in case individuals crossed between the grids. The mass, sex, approximate age class and species was recorded for each individual.

section.title: vegetation survey
section.para: . During our initial assessment of the study sites, it was noted that the vegetation was considerably sparser and drier than the previous year, and that the closed waterhole site had burned recently (see Figure 2). We assessed the vegetation at each grid along 100 m transects, which were laid out from the periphery of the water trough through the center of the grid. At 10 m intervals we estimated visibility perpendicular to the transect at heights of 10 and 50 cm. This was done by measuring the distance at which >50 percent of an object was obscured when viewed from each of the two heights. We used these heights as a representation of the effects of grass cover on rodent visibility, assuming that visibility plays a role in habitat preference. Percent grass cover was estimated every ten meters within a 50 cm × 50 cm quadrat. We measured grass species composition by identifying the grass species closest to the transect line every 2 m along the transect.

section.title: Startistical analyses
section.para: We used Microsoft Excel to compile our data and Stats Alive to perform ratio analyses to determine whether there was a significantly higher trap success rate in long versus short traps or any significant edge effect. All other statistical analyses were performed using Primer and Statistica. Using Primer, we calculated species similarity values for the vegetation transects and rodent trapping gridsand we calculated the Simpson’s diversity index for the grass community at each grid. We used Simpson’s measure of alpha diversity because it produces a weighted species richness measure using the probability of selecting two individuals of the same species at random from the same community. We used Statistica to perform t-tests to look for significant differences between the open and closed transects in terms of the percent grass cover and visibility.

We used the Peterson method to estimate the population of rodents at each site, which uses the unbiased estimator equation: N = (((M+1)(C+1))/(R+1)) -1, where M = number of individuals marked in the first sample, C = total number of individuals captured in the second sample and R = number of individuals in second sample that are marked (Krebs 1999). We combined the capture numbers for both grids within each site to avoid overestimating the population since there had been crossover of individuals between grids.
